awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT:  Smart Gloves for Remote Clinical Assessments and Treatment Monitoring
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation-Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is to enhance the quality of care provided to patients with movement disorders such as Parkinson's disease, stroke, arthritis, and hand injuries or other conditions. Parkinson's disease (PD) alone has a very high prevalence in the US. PD will affect nearly 930,000 people by 2020 and is projected to increase to 1.2 Million by 2030. Through the incorporation of wearable technology for clinically valid movement assessment, doctors can utilize telemedicine tools to provide a more optimized care plan to their patients without increasing the number of regular clinic visits. The patients will benefit as well through a friendly guided exercise routine that can be performed at home. The quantified results of the exercises will be given to the patients in a way that will help them understand the effects of medications and will provide data to doctors to inform decisions about medication changes. The proposed technology product aims to improve efficiency and reduce the cost for medical treatments. 

The proposed project aims to pursue research on developing smart textiles that are appropriate for clinically-valid medical screening of movement conditions especially those seen in Parkinson's disease. Smart textile fabrication faces several roadblocks and technical barriers including the integration of conductive material in conventional fabric and washability and durability of smart textiles. In addition, the selection of materials and construction methods significantly impacts the sensitivity, repeatability, accuracy, and precision of smart textile sensors. The proposed project aims to address these challenges through two aims: 1) AIM 1 focuses on design and validation of smart textile sensors. This activity involves a series of developments and experiments in collaboration with neurologists, medical personnel, and patients with PD who will jointly participate in the design of the proposed smart gloves. 2) AIM 2 will be centered around creating a manufacturer-friendly design of the smart gloves. The aim is to investigate how the complex structure of smart textiles (due to electrical circuits, conductive threads and layers, and base fabric) can be made at scale within existing fabrication facilities and processes. This project builds directly from fundamental research discovery supported by the NSF.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The PFI-TT Project was conducted at the Wearable Biosensing Lab, University of Rhode Island. The project was aimed at designing a pair of smart gloves for monitoring the symptoms of Parkinson's disease in home settings. 

Over the course of the project, the design of smart gloves underwent several iterations. In the first generation gloves, resistive flex sensors were used as inserts in the finger pockets to measure the fine finger movements. The first generation design had no exposed electronics and looked like regular gloves. However, they face the challenges of usability. For example, people with Parkinson?s disease found it difficult to insert their fingers in the gloves. They already have challenges to wear regular gloves because of movement impairments posed by the disease. We conducted a comparison study to measure the performance of the smart gloves against the 3D motion capture camera system.    

To address the challenges of the first generation design, a three finger glove design was implemented as the second generation glove. The location of the flex sensors was experimented and adjusted to ensure that the fine movement monitoring can be made more sensitive. Although the electronics module was visible, people with Parkinson?s disease show no concern to use them. The wearability of these gloves improved compared to the first generation. A specialized hardware module was created to acquire and communicate the sensor data from the glove to a tablet. The module has an inertial measurement unit (IMU) for monitoring motion. Essentially, the gloves are capable of monitoring 12-channel movement parameters including three fingers and 9-degree of freedom of hand motion.  

We deployed a glove kit in the homes of four people with Parkinson?s who used them for 2-3 weeks. The in-home kit includes a pair of smart gloves, a touch screen tablet, and charging accessories. Overall, the in-home usability study was successful. We collected 80 sets of glove data that included the movement exercises involving gross and fine motor movements of the hands and arms. We also collected a daily survey on sleep and quality of life domains. The dataset is allowing us to correlate how the symptoms of Parkinson?s are impacted by the medication dosage and timing as well as daily life activities. At the moment, we are expanding the in-home study to collect data from more people with Parkinson?s disease to validate a clinical hypothesis. 

In the last stage of this project, we put an effort to make the gloves design manufacturable with the consideration of human factors and ergonomics. We brought in a textile designer and also collaborated with a local industry. We performed a participatory design study in which we invited four people with Parkinson?s disease to help design the gloves that can address the concerns of wearability. Affinity mapping was used to condense observations made individually by team members across tasks and participants with Parkinson?s. This analysis helped identify preferred mechanisms, glove design opportunities, and mechanics to avoid. Based on the observation summary, various glove concept designs were brainstormed by the team and filtered down at different stages on the basis of usability and design viability to three design concepts for prototyping and evaluation and then sensorization. The selected designs sought to improve finger and wrist insertion and removal within the glove designs. We also used rapid prototyping methods for textile design. In this way, we were able to produce the gloves in a short period of time. This allowed us to test the prototypes on participants iteratively and acquire their feedback. We aim to expand the participatory design study to include more participants with Parkinson?s.    

Several scientific publications have been published based on the PFI-TT project. Research in this project was a part of two PhD dissertations and one MS thesis that focus on smart textiles, wearable sensors, and body sensor networks. Several undergraduate students gained research experience and went on to pursue higher education or industrial jobs in the research domains of this project. 

One of the PhD students ventured into a startup, EchoWear, on digital health technologies. With the support of the PFI-TT project funds, EchoWear completed an NSF I-Corps Cohort training and interviewed 110 stakeholders as a part of the customer discovery process. The I-Corps training turned out to be a pivotal moment for EchoWear. The startup has received small business development funds from NSF, NIH, and the state of RI government to translate research-backed concepts into commercialisable solutions.  The initial success of EchoWear has sparked entrepreneurial interest among STEM students at URI and local communities. 

 

 


Last Modified: 05/01/2022
Modified by: Kunal Mankodiya
por.por_txt_cntn:
The PFI-TT Project was conducted at the Wearable Biosensing Lab, University of Rhode Island. The project was aimed at designing a pair of smart gloves for monitoring the symptoms of Parkinson's disease in home settings. 
Over the course of the project, the design of smart gloves underwent several iterations. In the first generation gloves, resistive flex sensors were used as inserts in the finger pockets to measure the fine finger movements. The first generation design had no exposed electronics and looked like regular gloves. However, they face the challenges of usability. For example, people with Parkinson?s disease found it difficult to insert their fingers in the gloves. They already have challenges to wear regular gloves because of movement impairments posed by the disease. We conducted a comparison study to measure the performance of the smart gloves against the 3D motion capture camera system.    
To address the challenges of the first generation design, a three finger glove design was implemented as the second generation glove. The location of the flex sensors was experimented and adjusted to ensure that the fine movement monitoring can be made more sensitive. Although the electronics module was visible, people with Parkinson?s disease show no concern to use them. The wearability of these gloves improved compared to the first generation. Overall, the in-home usability study was successful. We collected 80 sets of glove data that included the movement exercises involving gross and fine motor movements of the hands and arms. We also collected a daily survey on sleep and quality of life domains. The dataset is allowing us to correlate how the symptoms of Parkinson?s are impacted by the medication dosage and timing as well as daily life activities. At the moment, we are expanding the in-home study to collect data from more people with Parkinson?s disease to validate a clinical hypothesis. 
In the last stage of this project, we put an effort to make the gloves design manufacturable with the consideration of human factors and ergonomics. We performed a participatory design study in which we invited four people with Parkinson?s disease to help design the gloves that can address the concerns of wearability. We aim to expand the participatory design study to include more participants with Parkinson?s.    
Several scientific publications have been published based on the PFI-TT project. Research in this project was a part of two PhD dissertations and one MS thesis that focus on smart textiles, wearable sensors, and body sensor networks. Several undergraduate students gained research experience and went on to pursue higher education or industrial jobs in the research domains of this project. 
One of the PhD students ventured into a startup, EchoWear, on digital health technologies. With the support of the PFI-TT project funds, EchoWear completed an NSF I-Corps Cohort training and interviewed 110 stakeholders as a part of the customer discovery process. The I-Corps training turned out to be a pivotal moment for EchoWear. The startup has received small business development funds from NSF, NIH, and the state of RI government to translate research-backed concepts into commercialisable solutions.  The initial success of EchoWear has sparked entrepreneurial interest among STEM students at URI and local communities.
